Award.AwardTitle: Nitric Oxide Transport Mechanisms: An Engineering approach

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0730547
Jaron

This proposal concerns the development a multi-scale approach to modeling nitric oxide production, transport and metabolism. A total of 5 objectives are stated for this proposal: (1) Expand an existing cell-scale model to include intracellular signaling and extra-cellular transport, (2) Couple a vascular-scale and cellular-scale model, (3) Develop a vascular network-scale model of NO transport, (4) Extend the model to a tissue level scale, and (5) Validate the theoretical simulations with in vitro and in vivo studies. The transport and metabolism of NO plays an important role in many normal and pathological tissue functions. As a result, this study could make important contributions to medicine and vascular physiology in general. The coupling of hemodynamics, multiple chemical reactions, and biophysical processes in an integrated multi-scale model is central to a vast number of important physiological and pathophysiological processes.

The coupling of the proposed research with existing courses and other education components is a strength of this proposal. In particular, including this work in cellular biomechanics, tissue engineering, and cardiovascular engineering course work will give students an opportunity to learn some cutting edge research. The PIs have a track record of including undergraduates in their research programs. Also, multi-scale and multi-temporal methods are becoming more important in biology and physiology. As a result, this work is likely to impact a number of other areas besides NO metabolism.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The importance of nitric oxide (NO) in regulating blood flow and metabolism is well established.  However, the mechanisms by which NO is produced and transported while undergoing reactions in blood and tissue have not been fully elucidated.  One of the central dilemmas is that while ample experimental data support a vasodilatory role for NO produced by the endothelium, the avid scavenging of NO by hemoglobin in the blood leads to predictions of sub-physiologic concentrations of NO in the vessel wall. We have, therefore, been developing an innovative model that could be used to advance our understanding of the complex interacting mechanisms and explain the discrepancy between predictions and observations. The development philosophy is to couple simulation of hemodynamics, chemical reactions and mechanical processes at the cell level with those at the vessel and tissue levels. The model is being developed in parallel with well-controlled experiments that allow validation of the model.

 

The research has broad impact on engineering science by developing complex modeling techniques that can be applied to other engineering and bioengineering problems. It also has broad impacts on biological and physiological systems by allowing prediction of behavior that is difficult or impossible to perform experimentally. The transport and metabolism of NO is important in many normal and pathophysiological functions. The coupling of hemodynamics, multiple chemical reactions and biophysical processes in an integrated model is central to many important biological processes. Therefore, this study is making important contributions to vascular physiology and medicine in general. In addition, the integrated approach is expected to yield important tools that can lead to improved understanding of the complete system and, importantly, help shed light on NO deficiency-related pathologies.

 


Last Modified: 04/09/2012
Modified by: Dov Jaron

The research has broad impact on engineering science by developing complex modeling techniques that can be applied to other engineering and bioengineering problems. The transport and metabolism of NO is important in many normal and pathophysiological functions. The coupling of hemodynamics, multiple chemical reactions and biophysical processes in an integrated model is central to many important biological processes.
